My Fragrance Voyage - The Palazzo Las Vegas - A Review

<p>It soars 642 feet above the famous Las Vegas Strip. Within its 53 floors, it houses 3000 ultra-posh suites, the world's most luxurious retail establish<a alt="gucci mens" title="gucci mens" href="http://www.gucci-outlets-factorys.com/gucci-men-bags-c-36.html]gucci mens[/url]ts and the chicest restaurants. I felt compelled to tour Vegas's newest luxury destination. This is my fragrance voyage at The Palazzo Las Vegas.</p>
<p><br />
<br />
<br />
 </p>
<p>I dressed in my shopping best as usual. But, this outfit was more casual; I wanted to feel relax during my tour. I wore Lee blue jeans, a ribbed forest green turtleneck by Perry Ellis, a brown leather Italian cut jacket and a pair of Stacy Adams shoes. Lastly, I brought along my favorite little wallet, the <a alt="gucci outlet" title="gucci outlet" href="http://www.gucci-outlets-factorys.com/2011-gucci-outlet-c-59.html]gucci outlet[/url] wallet.</p>
<p><br />
<br />
<br />
 </p>
<p>I jumped into my faithful truck and drove to the Palazzo. Parking was a breeze. There was a space waiting for me in its multi-level subterranean public garage, which is a bit unusual for the Strip. Most parking garages on the Strip are large monstrous things that are usually hidden behind the Strip's more glamorous facades. I thought the Sands Corporation, the owner of the Venetian and the Palazzo, chose a good location for the garage; it gives the Palazzo a more cosmopolitan flair.</p>
<p><br />
<br />
<br />
 </p>
<p>I exited my truck and walked into a glass enclosure. I stepped onto an escalator and was whisked to the casino/lobby level. The Palazzo's casino was like most large casinos on the Strip: thousands of colorful and noisy slot and poker machines and many green-topped gambling tables. I decided to leave the casino and headed towards the Palazzo's grand lobby. The appearance of the lobby was what I expected. It was elegant and very grand. I saw a beautiful fountain in its center that stood under a large glass cupola. It was surrounded by voluptuous glass naked temptresses, encouraging the patrons of the hotel to live their sinful dreams. It was a very beautiful centerpiece. Since I was intrigued by the architectural influences of the Palazzo's lobby and the rest of the hotel, I asked the concierge which country or culture influenced the hotel's architecture. He explained that it was based on  the buildings of Continental Europe. However, old world Italian design was the main architectural paradigm. I was satisfied with his answer, and I proceeded to the real part of my fragrance voyage, visiting <i>The Shoppes at The Palazzo</i>.</p>
<p><br />
<br />
<br />
 </p>
<p>The first shop I visited was <i>Fresh</i>, the upscale and niche fragrance perfumery. The store wasn't opened to the public, but the shop's manager gave me permission to explore it. It was designed like most upscale perfumeries yet with a little twist -- very bright, plenty of glass, understated yet very contemporary. The manager told me that Fresh was owned by the luxury conglomerate LVMH, who happened to own Guerlain and Louis Vuitton. She mentioned her company moved to the Palazzo since they were adding stores to many luxury destinations. In other words, Fresh was in a high growth mode.</p>
<p><br />
<br />
<br />
 </p>
<p>I asked her about the most popular fragrance among her clients. She mentioned that Sake was the bestselling one. According to Osmoz, this fragrance is "sensual and delicate, it was inspired by Japanese beauty rituals. Blending unusual notes of langsat, an Asian plant, with fruity waves of white peach and Chinese osmanthus blossom." Other popular fragrances according to the manager were <i>Sugar Lychee</i> for women, a fruity-floral fragrance, and <i>Cannabis Santal</i> for men, an oriental-woody scent. I thanked the manager for taking the time to speak with me and I proceeded on my voyage.</p>
<p><br />
<br />
<br />
 </p>
<p>As I walked to my next retail destination, I passed by Tony Burch, the fashion house that is known for creating sophisticated fashion for women at an accessible price point. <p><br />

 </p>

<br />
<br />
 </p>

<p><br />

<br />
 </p>

He responded that the retailer is unique when it comes to fragrances. It carries mostly niche scents. In other words, many colognes and perfumes that are sold in Barneys are available either in the perfume designers' boutiques or Barneys. His answer impressed me. A few minutes later after I spoke with the fragrance expert, I was swept up by a cute middle-aged blond woman. She became my personal guide in this section and introduced me to the fragrances of <i>Aqua di Parma</i>.
